"To clear. up any misconceptions which might arise," said Os
Steinwald, "I want to point out
that the dance is open to the
entire school. I know there are
some people who are of the opinion that only members of the

may attend. This is not true. I
want. to extend an invitation to
all the classes."

two classes have sponsored to
date."

"We the students of JHU have
self imposed a code of ethics to
guarantee high standards of condust. We should remember that
this code of ethics applies to the
behavior of students on the campus or at the location of the campus-sponsored activities and not
only to conduct in class and examination rooms.
"The conduct displayed on the
night of the Senior Class party
at the ROTC building was below
that of a true Hopkins man."
Senior Class President Mayer
Liebman stated, "I was shocked
and disappointed when I discovered the full extent of the
damage. It didn't seem possible
that any Hopkins men could have
been involved in such a senseless
incident.
"Thanks to the diligence of the
Plant Manager's office, the bill
will not be as great as was previously estimated. This is encouragaing to the class finance but
does not, in the least, ease the
seriousness of the whole affair.
"Such a breach of the Gentleman's Code can not be so lightly
excused. The good name and honor of the under-graduate body
has a smear upon it which will
linger for some time to come."
Peinado said, "The Student
Council has appointed a committee of six men to investigate the
damages at the ROTC building.
This committee will try too determine the individuals responsible for the damages incurred
and will require that they pay
accordingly.
"Anyone with any pertinent information should write a note,
with his name and post office
box, to the Student Council, Box
1246."

By DON KRAFT •
Dr. Grayson Louis Kirk, prezident of Columbia University, will be the principal speaker in Commemoration Day
ceremonies to be held next Wednesday at 11 a.m.•in Shriver
Hall in celebration of the eightieth anniversary of the founding of Johns Hopkins University.
The occasion will also mark the centennial of the birth
of President Woodrow Wilson who was a Hopkins alumnus.
Dr. Lowell J. Reed, president of
Hopkins, will preside over the
Commemoration Day exercises
and will confer an honorary degree upon Dr. Kirk.
Rowell Leads
The academic procession will
be led by Professor Henry T. Rowell, chief
marshal. Professor
Fritz Machlup will head the division made up by the university
president, guests, and trustees;
while Professor Walter Koski and
Assistant Professor Willis Gore
will lead the faculties.
The program will include two
selections by the Hopkins Glee
Club which were sung by the first
Hopkins Glee Club in the convocation program of 1884. This
first glee club, formed through
the efforts of first tenor WoodDR. GRAYSON KIRK
row Wilson, sang "Integer Vitae"
and "Gaudeamus."
In his address, "Universities
and Public Service," Dr. Kirk will
refer to the influence of Woodrow Wilson's early scholarly training on his later public life. Many

DSRC Constitution Fails
To Get Past Committee
Chairman Don Gallagher of The
Dormitory Students Representative Council's sub-committee on
constitutions said Tuesday that
his committee "didn't have the
time" between October, when the
committee was established to draw
up a new constitution, and this
week to compose the proposed
document.
He explained that he "didn't
think it was that important' to
get the constitution to the dorm
students for ratification.
Jones Commends
DSRC President Carleton Jones
had said, in October, that the new
constitution would be ready for
student consideration by the
middle of November.

Graduate Students To Hold
Informal Mixer Next Week
Graduate Students are invited
to attend an informal mixer to
be held in Levering Hall on Friday, February 24, announced
Walter Sanders, chairman of the
Graduate Students Association
Social Committee.
Tickets will cost $.50 for nonmembers and $.25 for members,
and are available at the Bookstore, from the GSA representatives, or at the door. Sanders
stated that the GSA expects an
increase in ticket sales over the
last dance, which drew approximately 125 people. Music will be
recorded:
Evans Elected
The GSA also held election of
officers last Monday, February 13.
Richard Evans, a student of Industrial Engineering, was elected
president, and Roy Edwards, who
Is studying Electrical Engineering, was chosen as vice-president.
Elected as treasurer was Miss
Natasha Potanin, an Australian
student in the Psychology Department who is also an instructor at
McCoy College. Miss Pat Cover,
in the Political Science Department, was elected secretary.

These officers will serve until
the same time next year. The
elections mark the first establishment of an indoctrination system
for graduate students entering in
the fall.
Schedule Socials
Sanders stated that, "T h e
Graduate Students Council is
trying to work up a program of
interesting activities for the graduates. The better the co-operation, the better the functions. At
present," he continued, "more
dances, a picnic, and a hayride
are scheduled for early spring".
Former GSA President Ken
Wiskind declared that the organization would like greater support
and more representatives. "The
activities are directly proportional to the response of interested
people," said Wiskind. "The students should feel free to attend
our council meetings."
Interested parties should report to room 104 in the Aeronautics Building on Mondays at 12:05
p.m.

Hopkins' Debate Council has
scheduled six more meets for the
near future, according to president Herb Butler.
These meets include contests at
Boston, Barnard College, Kings
College, and the University of
Virginia. This week two teams of
debaters will be sent to Kings
College in Wilkesbury, Pa., to
represent the Hopkins. Herb Butler and Lesley Norens will comprise an affirmative group, while
Bill Willoughby and Lew Sank
form the negative team. The team
will travel to Boston next week
and follow that with a trip to
Barnard College in New York.

Barnstormers To Presen

Hopkins'Glee Club
Concert Schedule
Most Complete Yet
The Hopkins Glee Club is in the
middle of its "most complete concert tour to date," according to
President Mayer Liebman.
The second semester began with
a Rogers and Hammerstein concert at the Lyric Theater in Baltimore with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and the Goucher
College Glee Club, under the direction of Herbert Grossman.
Liebman said, "It was a great
honor for us (to appear with the
Symphony) and we certainly appreciate the opportunity to sing
there (at the Lyric)." A standing-room-only crowd heard the
concert.
The Glee Club will sing twice on
'Commemoration Day, February
22, once at Shriver Hall, continuing the tradition of the first glee
club, and then that evening at
the Sheraton-Belvedere alumni
banquet.
Concerning the tour program,
the Club will sing at Wilson College for Women March 16, while
on March 24, it will sing at the
Hotel Dennis in Atlantic City.
April 6 is the date for a planned
concert for the New York alumni
chapter, and on April 14, a concert and mixer dance, at which
the Blue Jays will play, will be
held at the Baltimore YWCA.
On.April 21, a Home Concert
and Dance, the "biggest event of
the year," will be held. Liebman
said he is "planning quite a big
affair." The year will be corn-

Yes,Dave,the Du Pont company regularly employs
stpdents of science and engineering in its Summer Technical.Training Program. The chief purpose is to provide
good technical training under industrial conditions. And
we learn about the students while they learn about us.
Students selected for the program after campus interviews include candidates for the B.S., M.S., and Ph.D.
degrees. Assignments are related to their academic interests. Last summer 270 students from 93 institutions
participated in the program. In this way, ties are often
established which can -lead to permanent employment
after graduation.
In addition, many other students are hired directly
by indievidual Company units to help out during vacation periods of our regular employees. For this "vacation
relief work," assignments are likely to be varied; but
these students also gain valuable insights into industrial
practice, and many acquire experience related to their
fields of study.
Altogether, about 750 college students, from both
technical and nontechnical fields and at all levels of
training, obtained experience with us during the summer
of 1955. So you can readily see, Dave,that the Du Pont
Company attaches a lot of importance to summer jobs
for college students.

The Block--A Socio- sychological View.„

The exotic atmosphere of the phrenologist's parlor.)(not the one mentioned in the article) is temPorarily shattered by the flash of the News-Letter cam era. Located at the extreme east of the Block, the
phrenology-fortune telling section is somewhat removed from the blinking lights and penny arcades.
As we walked east on Baltimore
Street, crossing Commerce, and
heading into "The Block," charcoal-clad executives and their
fur-bearing wives melted into
banana-hawkers and sub-debs in
kerchiefs, silk jackets, and levis.
In the three or four blocks from
Commerce to Market Place are
concentrated Baltimore's stripper
palaces, gaudy night spots,
dollar hotels, palmists, shooting
galleries and pin-ball parlors, sellers of erotica and itching powder,
and hock shops, with their banjos

and

and binoculars.

door pulp-magazine stand.
Burlesque shows start at noon
on Baltimore Street, but "The
Block" in daytime, people-wise,
is only a little more seedy than
its ordinary down-town environs.
The barber-shops are busy, jewelry is on sale at $3.75 for an
"emerald" and $8.95 for a "diamond," surplus stores offer anything from gas-masks to tanker
jackets, tattered entrepreneurs
sell oranges and bananas, and
beggers rattle pencils in tin cups.
Bosses and their secretaries
grab hurried lunches in corner
drugstores, talking of contracts

"The telephone people I met," says
Forrest, "were always helpful. I considered them the experts. They gave a
very good impression of the Bell System.
So three months before I was discharged
I wrote to Indiana Bell for an interview,
and subsequently I was hired as a
Student Engineer."
Today Forrest is in Indiana Bell's
Engineering Department, working with

carrier facilities—the means by whiGh a
number of telephone calls can be sent
simultaneously over one circuit.
Forrest is given the basic circuit and
equipment requirements for a job. "My
boss farms it out to me," Forrest says,
"and I take it from scratch,:' Forrest
does the complete engineering job. He
writes the specifications, including wiring plans and the list of equipment for
file job. Then the installers take over.
"I really feel that I'm contributing
to the telephone business," Forrest says.
"My wife does too. When we're in the
car we get a kick out of driving by a
job that I engineered. Nothing can compare with a career in a business' that's
growing as fast as the Bell System. It's
the place to move ahead."

Forrest graduated in 1952 from Purdue
University with an E.E. degree. His career is
typical of those which exist in other Bell Telephone Companies, and in Bell Telephone
Laboratories, Western Electric and Sandia
Corporation. Your placement officer has more
information about Bell System companies.

Correspondence
Sacred?
Dear Sir:
Are constitutions sacred? Well,
no; but then just what is a constitution? A Constitution is a
body of law and rules of procedure which has been accepted
by a certain majority of the
members of an organization. They
agree one and all as members of
the organization to abide by that
constitution and its provisions
until such time as they may be
changed according to the provisions for amendment contained
in the constitution.
It would seem that the members of the organization assume
that all business of the organization will be carried on under the
constitution. It would also appear
that organizations and governments to best when operated under this system over the long run.
After observing the activities of
the SAC, I would say that this
group agrees in principle with the
above statements. In my opinion
It has always been particularly

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FEB. 17, 1956

anxious that an organization have
an approved constitution and that
it follow that constitution. I could
not agree more whole-heartedly
with such policy.
It is therefore with some confusion that I note the recent action•of the SAC whereby it allowed

Without pointing out my personal opinions regarding the
dangers involved whenever one
group in any organization is allowed to suspend the constitution,
I would like to ask the SAC why
this action was deemed so necessary that, in fact, it reversed its
heretofore policy in regards to the
value of a constitutional form of
government.
The Control Board of the Radio
Station seemed to think that it
was necessary to take this action
because they did not want to wait
for the required one week dc
manded by the constitution before the final election could take
place. However, concerning one of
the posts to be filled, that one
week had passed and that election could have carried out
immediately and constitutionally!
This was not done. In view of
this fact, one can only wonder
what the real reasons were for the
suspension of the constitution.
JOHN LAMBERT

Into The China Shop
The actual workings of a system of non-academic honor
have long been suffering from a fuzzy indefiniteness. The Student Council has hovered tentatively in the
background with a vague constitutional provision giving
it, in the words of its president, "jurisdiction over all undergraduates," but its activity has been potential, not actual,
Dean Shaffer dealing individually with all such cases.
Now the situation has been altered by the need to
collect reparations for the damage done at the ROTC
building during the recent senior "blast." The SC, conscious that the administration has been dissatisfied with
its inactivity, has hurriedly set up an ad hoc committee, to
"investigate" the situation and "require" the individuals
it has adjudged "guilty" to pay the costs of the vandalism.
this is written, will play its proThis committee,
ceedings entirely by ear no decisions have been made as to
how "guilt" will be determined, what provision will be
made for appeal, what percentage of the group is needed
to arrive at a verdict, how its decisions are to be carried
out, if the "guilty" person refuses to pay it lacks, in short,
any judicial character whatsoever, which is not surprising,
since it is a fragment of an elected body, undertaking under
stress to clear up promptly a messy situation.
But there is more involved here than the payment of
a few plumber's and carpenter's bills. The attitude of
the Dean's office toward student self-administration and
government and the significance of the Student Council
itself are vitally concerned.
Yet we cannot commend the SC for this departure
from its customary sloth. Rushing to the solution of a
particular situation, they have overlooked two facets of
the general problem: (1) that a little pre-concerted observation by SC members of situations where violations
of the Gentleman's Code are prone to occur could prevent these occasional incidents, and (2) that IF the SC
is to assert its long-dormant "jurisdiction" over undergraduates, it must first work out very carefully with the administration and the student body the judicial methods
and stated limitations under which the body, to which the SC
delegates the responsibility for this new function, should
operate.

Rifle Coach Forsees
Victorious Season
Having built up a 7-1 record so
far this season, the Hopkins' rifle
team has been picked by their
Coach, Sgt. Charles Brown, to win
their final eight matches.
The only loss of the season
came on January 14 at the hands
of Georgetown. The big match of
the season, however, is the triangular match in April with LaSalle and Temple at Philadelphia.
Brown predicts a victory for the
Jays.
Top marksman for Hopkins this
year is Roger Van Riper with a
275 average. He is followed by
Harvey Kasinoff and Bob Edwards with averages of 268 and
266, respectively. Number four
man on the team is Don Griggs
with a 264 average:
The Hopkins ROTC rifle. team
also has won honors, having won
the Maryland Military District
Championship. Don Griggs won
the trophey for the highest individual score.

In Final Dual Meet

With the possibility of a MasonDixon
Conference tournament
berth on the line, the Jay Hoopsters travel to Ashland, Virginia
tomorrow night to battle Randolph-Macon.

"We the students of JHU have

"The conduct displayed on the

Senior Class President Mayer

linger for some time to come."

Dr. Grayson Louis Kirk, prezident of Columbia University, will be the principal speaker in Commemoration Day
ceremonies to be held next Wednesday at 11 a.m.•in Shriver
Hall in celebration of the eightieth anniversary of the founding of Johns Hopkins University.
The occasion will also mark the centennial of the birth
of President Woodrow Wilson who was a Hopkins alumnus.
Dr. Lowell J. Reed, president of
Hopkins, will preside over the
Commemoration Day exercises
and will confer an honorary degree upon Dr. Kirk.
Rowell Leads
The academic procession will
be led by Professor Henry T. Rowell, chief
marshal. Professor
Fritz Machlup will head the division made up by the university
president, guests, and trustees;
while Professor Walter Koski and
Assistant Professor Willis Gore
will lead the faculties.
The program will include two
selections by the Hopkins Glee
Club which were sung by the first
Hopkins Glee Club in the convocation program of 1884. This
first glee club, formed through
the efforts of first tenor WoodDR. GRAYSON KIRK
row Wilson, sang "Integer Vitae"
and "Gaudeamus."

and Public Service," Dr. Kirk will

week to compose the proposed

He explained that he "didn't
think it was that important' to
get the constitution to the dorm
students for ratification.
Jones Commends

had said, in October, that the new

Graduate Students To Hold
Informal Mixer Next Week
Graduate Students are invited
to attend an informal mixer to
be held in Levering Hall on Friday, February 24, announced
Walter Sanders, chairman of the
Graduate Students Association
Social Committee.
Tickets will cost $.50 for nonmembers and $.25 for members,
and are available at the Bookstore, from the GSA representatives, or at the door. Sanders
stated that the GSA expects an
increase in ticket sales over the
last dance, which drew approximately 125 people. Music will be
recorded:
Evans Elected
The GSA also held election of
officers last Monday, February 13.
Richard Evans, a student of Industrial Engineering, was elected
president, and Roy Edwards, who
Is studying Electrical Engineering, was chosen as vice-president.
Elected as treasurer was Miss
Natasha Potanin, an Australian
student in the Psychology Department who is also an instructor at
McCoy College. Miss Pat Cover,
in the Political Science Department, was elected secretary.

These officers will serve until
the same time next year. The
elections mark the first establishment of an indoctrination system
for graduate students entering in
the fall.
Schedule Socials
Sanders stated that, "T h e
Graduate Students Council is
trying to work up a program of
interesting activities for the graduates. The better the co-operation, the better the functions. At
present," he continued, "more
dances, a picnic, and a hayride
are scheduled for early spring".
Former GSA President Ken
Wiskind declared that the organization would like greater support
and more representatives. "The
activities are directly proportional to the response of interested
people," said Wiskind. "The students should feel free to attend
our council meetings."
Interested parties should report to room 104 in the Aeronautics Building on Mondays at 12:05
p.m.

Hopkins' Debate Council has
scheduled six more meets for the
near future, according to president Herb Butler.
These meets include contests at
Boston, Barnard College, Kings
College, and the University of
Virginia. This week two teams of
debaters will be sent to Kings
College in Wilkesbury, Pa., to
represent the Hopkins. Herb Butler and Lesley Norens will comprise an affirmative group, while
Bill Willoughby and Lew Sank
form the negative team. The team
will travel to Boston next week
and follow that with a trip to
Barnard College in New York.

Yes,Dave,the Du Pont company regularly employs
stpdents of science and engineering in its Summer Technical.Training Program. The chief purpose is to provide
good technical training under industrial conditions. And
we learn about the students while they learn about us.
Students selected for the program after campus interviews include candidates for the B.S., M.S., and Ph.D.
degrees. Assignments are related to their academic interests. Last summer 270 students from 93 institutions
participated in the program. In this way, ties are often
established which can -lead to permanent employment
after graduation.
In addition, many other students are hired directly
by indievidual Company units to help out during vacation periods of our regular employees. For this "vacation
relief work," assignments are likely to be varied; but
these students also gain valuable insights into industrial
practice, and many acquire experience related to their
fields of study.
Altogether, about 750 college students, from both
technical and nontechnical fields and at all levels of
training, obtained experience with us during the summer
of 1955. So you can readily see, Dave,that the Du Pont
Company attaches a lot of importance to summer jobs
for college students.

"The telephone people I met," says
Forrest, "were always helpful. I considered them the experts. They gave a
very good impression of the Bell System.
So three months before I was discharged
I wrote to Indiana Bell for an interview,
and subsequently I was hired as a
Student Engineer."
Today Forrest is in Indiana Bell's
Engineering Department, working with

carrier facilities—the means by whiGh a
number of telephone calls can be sent
simultaneously over one circuit.
Forrest is given the basic circuit and
equipment requirements for a job. "My
boss farms it out to me," Forrest says,
"and I take it from scratch,:' Forrest
does the complete engineering job. He
writes the specifications, including wiring plans and the list of equipment for
file job. Then the installers take over.
"I really feel that I'm contributing
to the telephone business," Forrest says.
"My wife does too. When we're in the
car we get a kick out of driving by a
job that I engineered. Nothing can compare with a career in a business' that's
growing as fast as the Bell System. It's
the place to move ahead."

Forrest graduated in 1952 from Purdue
University with an E.E. degree. His career is
typical of those which exist in other Bell Telephone Companies, and in Bell Telephone

Corporation. Your placement officer has more

Correspondence
Sacred?
Dear Sir:
Are constitutions sacred? Well,
no; but then just what is a constitution? A Constitution is a
body of law and rules of procedure which has been accepted
by a certain majority of the
members of an organization. They
agree one and all as members of
the organization to abide by that
constitution and its provisions
until such time as they may be
changed according to the provisions for amendment contained
in the constitution.
It would seem that the members of the organization assume
that all business of the organization will be carried on under the
constitution. It would also appear
that organizations and governments to best when operated under this system over the long run.
After observing the activities of
the SAC, I would say that this
group agrees in principle with the
above statements. In my opinion
It has always been particularly

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, FEB. 17, 1956

anxious that an organization have
an approved constitution and that
it follow that constitution. I could
not agree more whole-heartedly
with such policy.
It is therefore with some confusion that I note the recent action•of the SAC whereby it allowed

Without pointing out my personal opinions regarding the
dangers involved whenever one
group in any organization is allowed to suspend the constitution,
I would like to ask the SAC why
this action was deemed so necessary that, in fact, it reversed its
heretofore policy in regards to the
value of a constitutional form of
government.
The Control Board of the Radio
Station seemed to think that it
was necessary to take this action
because they did not want to wait
for the required one week dc
manded by the constitution before the final election could take
place. However, concerning one of
the posts to be filled, that one
week had passed and that election could have carried out
immediately and constitutionally!
This was not done. In view of
this fact, one can only wonder
what the real reasons were for the
suspension of the constitution.
JOHN LAMBERT

Into The China Shop
The actual workings of a system of non-academic honor
have long been suffering from a fuzzy indefiniteness. The Student Council has hovered tentatively in the
background with a vague constitutional provision giving
it, in the words of its president, "jurisdiction over all undergraduates," but its activity has been potential, not actual,
Dean Shaffer dealing individually with all such cases.
Now the situation has been altered by the need to
collect reparations for the damage done at the ROTC
building during the recent senior "blast." The SC, conscious that the administration has been dissatisfied with
its inactivity, has hurriedly set up an ad hoc committee, to
"investigate" the situation and "require" the individuals
it has adjudged "guilty" to pay the costs of the vandalism.
this is written, will play its proThis committee,
ceedings entirely by ear no decisions have been made as to
how "guilt" will be determined, what provision will be
made for appeal, what percentage of the group is needed
to arrive at a verdict, how its decisions are to be carried
out, if the "guilty" person refuses to pay it lacks, in short,
any judicial character whatsoever, which is not surprising,
since it is a fragment of an elected body, undertaking under
stress to clear up promptly a messy situation.
But there is more involved here than the payment of
a few plumber's and carpenter's bills. The attitude of
the Dean's office toward student self-administration and
government and the significance of the Student Council
itself are vitally concerned.
Yet we cannot commend the SC for this departure
from its customary sloth. Rushing to the solution of a
particular situation, they have overlooked two facets of
the general problem: (1) that a little pre-concerted observation by SC members of situations where violations
of the Gentleman's Code are prone to occur could prevent these occasional incidents, and (2) that IF the SC
is to assert its long-dormant "jurisdiction" over undergraduates, it must first work out very carefully with the administration and the student body the judicial methods
and stated limitations under which the body, to which the SC
delegates the responsibility for this new function, should
operate.

SPORTS SECTION
Jays Battle Randolph-Macon
Tomorrow Night At Ashland

Rifle Coach Forsees
Victorious Season
Having built up a 7-1 record so
far this season, the Hopkins' rifle
team has been picked by their
Coach, Sgt. Charles Brown, to win
their final eight matches.
The only loss of the season
came on January 14 at the hands
of Georgetown. The big match of
the season, however, is the triangular match in April with LaSalle and Temple at Philadelphia.
Brown predicts a victory for the
Jays.
Top marksman for Hopkins this
year is Roger Van Riper with a
275 average. He is followed by
Harvey Kasinoff and Bob Edwards with averages of 268 and
266, respectively. Number four
man on the team is Don Griggs
with a 264 average:
The Hopkins ROTC rifle. team
also has won honors, having won
the Maryland Military District
Championship. Don Griggs won
the trophey for the highest individual score.

Jays To Meet Loyola
In Final Dual Meet

With the possibility of a MasonDixon
Conference tournament
berth on the line, the Jay Hoopsters travel to Ashland, Virginia
tomorrow night to battle Randolph-Macon.

The Johns Hopkins Unversity
matmen, unvictorious to date, will
have their last chance to post a
dual match victory tomorrow
night at 8:00 p.m. when they
match holds with the Greyhounds
of Loyola College.
Although this will be the final
dual match of the season, it will
not ring down the curtain on the
1955-56 mat campaign. Next Friday and Saturday, February 24-25,
Towson Teachers will be host to
the annual Mason-Dixon ConferWrestling
ence
Tournament,
which will decide the Conference
champion as well as the individual
titlists. Seedings for this tourney
will be decided by the M-D
coaches at a meeting on the morning of the 24th.
Loyola, as does Hopkins, brings
an 0-5 seasonal mark into tomorrow's fray. The 'Hounds' last opponent, Western Maryland, blanked them by a 38-0 score, as only
performer, Larry
one Loyola
D'Orazio, managed to escape being pinned by the Terrors. Last
season, the Jays subdued their
Charles Street rivals.

Randolph-Macon has had a
poor year thus far, having compiled a 1-11 conference record as
of Monday. However, Hopkins
Coach Ross Sachs feels that the
Yellow Jackets are capable of
giving the Blue Jays a real battle,
particularly on their home floor.
Coach Sachs calls the Yellow
Jackets an "average size" club
with their scoring punch built
around their center, Joiner. The
JHU mentor will open the game
with the same lineup which has
been starting throughout the
year, but warns that the Blue
Jays must show a marked improvement over recent outings to
win. Randolp h-Macon's only
Mason-Dixon victory was over
Hampden-Sydney, who conquered
Hopkins last week.
Lose Last Four
After compiling a 4-0 conference record in the first half of
the season, the Jays hit the skids
_on returning to the hardwood
after exams, dropping four
straight games, three of them
-conference tilts.
In their first tilt after the midterm break, the Blue Jays ran
afoul of Hampden-Sydney and
dropped their first Mason-Dixon
game by a 73-59 count. Then, in
succession, defeats were suffered
at the hands of Washington and
Lee, Loyola, and Western Maryland, the Washington and Lee
game being the only one outside
of the conference.

victories by 5-2,5-3 and 5-1 scores.
He even went so far as to say
that "the saber team of Forte,
Dick Heckman, and Darryl Carter was one of the best around.

a 2-1 slate. The team took the
event, 6-3.

Jays Lose 26-10
Last Saturday, the Jay g,rappiers journeyed to Collegeville, Pa.
to face the Bears of Ursinus and
came out on the short end of a
26-10 score, as only Sam Wright
and Frank Young were able to
score victories for Hopkins.
Dave Hochberg, hampered by a
chest injury, was pinned by the
Bears' Don Durr in 7:25 in the
123 pound division. After being
out of action since before the

Christmas holiday.s, Frank Young
returned to the mats for the
Black--and-Blue and scored a fall
over George Miyazaki in 5:20.
Coach Wilson Fewster was gratified by this victory and had high
praise for Young, who showed no
signs of the injury that had
plagued him.
Dick Padula, Mid-Atlantic Conference 137 pound champion and
Bear captain, defeated Bob Partridge by a 4-0 count. Partridge
and Padula attended the same
high school in Upper Darby, with
Padula graduating a year before
Partridge. Fewster stated that
was one of the best grapplers that
he has seen all season, and that
he was pleased with the performance of Partridge even though he
was defeated.
Connor Upset 7-5
In the 140 pound division, Tony
Cianei upset the Jays' Co-captain
Bob Connor by a 7-5 score; while
157-pounder Mel Alexanderwicz
was pinned by tne Bears' Jack
Prestman in 7:50, and Dick Heyot,
highly touted Ursinus grappler at
167 pound scored a fall over Dick
Watts.
Because of the ankle injury of
Mike Caldwell and the initiation,
Mike McLaughlin was Coach Fewster's choice in the 177 pound
class. Mike, however, was pinned
in 2:59 by Ray Knapp in a match
that featured both men considerably under the 177 pound limit.
Sam Wright captured the unlimited division bout by forfeit
due to a shoulder injury which
the 'Bears' heavyweight suffered
during the week.

Last Saturday the Frosh rallied
to take a 83-74 victory against
Western Maryland after a 44-44
halftime tie. In the third quarter
the Junior Blue Jays pulled
away to a 11 point lead and

coasted the rest of the way. Dick
Weinstein dumped in 21 markers
and was aided by Billy Morrill
and Ed Bernstein who tallied 18
and 14 points, respectively.
Hopkins took a closely-fought
contest, 80-73, against a stubborn
Bainbridge five on the opposition's
court on Tuesday. Led by the
scoring of Morrill with 24 points
and the 19 point output of Weinstein, the Jays overcame a 36-30
halftime deficit, mainly due to
their inefficiency at the foul line
(2-13).
The Naps used a 2-1-2 sliding
zone, but the Birds had no trouble
getting off shots as they hit for

62% from the floor. Bainbridge
managed to keep a six point lead
throughout the third quarter and
up to the final four minutes in
the last frame. With the use of
a press, the Hopkins' five tied the
score 71-71 with two minutes left
to play. Morrill and Al Seivold
broke loose for eight fast points
and that was enoughfor the victory. Scott commented, "we managed to get by their press and
